An airport of any city is very often the first and last impression you have of a city. In some sense it reflects the ethos of the city you are leaving and that of those who run, and subsequently represent it. I honestly can't understand what the hoopla is all about at IGI Terminal 1. Very unsavoury experience. The entire section with the food court is without AC and the day we landed it was a scorching 43 degrees. When it comes to the departure gates, the ratio of seats to passengers is 1:9 easily. I understand that they're refurbishing but isn't there a shred of humanity? They could have provided makeshift chairs for people. They could have had mobile coolers in the spaces that are not air-conditioned. I had to have my kids sit on the floor. It astounds me that they have space that they've reserved for couches that can have one person lolling around in a huge space while kids, senior citizens who didn't manage to reserve a spot in advance are just standing around. What really broke my heart was that there was a lady with a little infant sitting on the floor as he slept. Etiquette and manners cascade and there's no one with an iota of consideration in this "celebrated" airport at the National Capital to teach the same to the people who frequent it. The actual boarding was a prime example in chaos. With haphazard organization, there were passengers running helter skelter to converge on this one bottleneck.
Even on the day we landed our flight was taxiing around for half an hour and then another half hour just to get an airstair. There were people with connections scrambling to get to the next leg of their journey.
Have been in some really tiny airports where airport staff and the general demeanour and functioning left us with much better impressions than this one. And airport management might want to keep in mind that we don't burn holes in our pockets to have stress-filled travel.
The entire episode made us really glad we were on our way out and not in!

Frequently, an airport serves as both your initial and final impression of a city. It is reflective of the culture of the city you are leaving behind as well as the people who govern and hence represent it, in a way. To be honest, I don't know what all the excitement is about at IGI Terminal 1. An extremely unpleasant experience. It was a sweltering 47 degrees on the day we arrived, and the entire area around the food court is without air conditioning.

The ratio of seats to passengers at the departure gates is easily 1:6. We know they're renovating, but isn't there at least a semblance of humanity? They could have given people temporary chairs. In the areas without air conditioning, they may have used portable coolers. The youngsters had to sit on the floor for me. I find it astounding that they have couches set out for one person to lounge on while children and elderly people who were unable to secure a spot ahead of time are left to stand around.
The fact that a mother was sitting her small child on the floor as he slept truly broke my heart. Manners and etiquette flow naturally, and nobody in this "celebrated" airport in the nation's capital seems to care enough to impart the same values to the passengers who use it. The actual boarding was a perfect illustration of disorder. Passengers were rushing haphazardly to congregate at this one bottleneck due to poor organization.
Even on the day of our landing, we spent 30 minutes taxiing around and an additional 30 minutes waiting for an airstair.
Some with connections were rushing to continue on to the next part of their adventure.

We've traveled to several incredibly small airports where the personnel, overall operation, and general attitude left us with far better impressions than this one. Additionally, airport management should remember that we don't burn through money for stressful travel.

I recently had the pleasure of traveling through the newly revamped Terminal 2 at Indira Gandhi International Airport (IGI), and I must say, it's a stunning transformation!

The moment I stepped into the terminal, I was struck by its sleek and modern design. The spacious interiors, high ceilings, and abundance of natural light make for a truly welcoming atmosphere. The terminal's architecture is a beautiful blend of Indian culture and contemporary style, with intricate patterns and motifs adorning the walls and ceilings.

The check-in and baggage drop process was seamless and efficient, with plenty of counters and friendly staff to assist. The security checks were also quick and hassle-free, with multiple scanners and courteous personnel.

One of the standout features of T2 is its incredible art installations and exhibits. The terminal is home to an impressive collection of Indian art and artifacts, including stunning sculptures, paintings, and textiles. The displays are beautifully curated and add a unique cultural dimension to the airport experience.

The food and beverage options at T2 are also excellent, with a wide range of Indian and international cuisine available. From traditional street food to fine dining restaurants, there's something for every taste and budget.

My only suggestion for improvement would be to add more seating areas and power outlets, as the terminal can get quite busy during peak travel times.

Overall, I was thoroughly impressed with Terminal 2 at IGI Airport. It's a world-class facility that showcases the best of Indian culture, design, and hospitality. If you're traveling through Delhi, T2 is definitely the terminal to choose!

The terminal provides essential services such as baggage handling and information counters, though some travelers have noted that the seating areas can be limited. The overall cleanliness and maintenance are up to standard, but occasional delays in security or boarding processes can occur. Despite these minor issues, T2 effectively handles a large volume of passengers and serves as a crucial part of IGI Airport‚Äôs infrastructure.

Delhi Cantt Railway Station, commonly referred to as Delhi Cantt or DEC, is an important railway junction located in the Delhi Cantonment area of the national capital, New Delhi. Constructed during the British colonial era in the early 1900s as part of the strategic military rail network, the station was primarily established to serve the needs of the Indian Army stationed in the cantonment. Positioned strategically between residential zones and military establishments, the station today plays a vital role in serving both civilian and defense-related transportation needs.
